I'm fairly new to using junit, but I would suspect that the advantage of
unit testing is getting a specific pointer to a section of code that has
been confirmed as wrong.  If you just tested with integration test you would
probably know something is wrong but might not be able to pinpoint where it
is wrong.  I would think your cost of fixing that error would be lower with
the unit test because you don't have to search for it.  Granted, you could
probably do just as well with the integration test, but isn't reassuring to
say I have fully tested all the objects that generate a given page and I
have confidence in them.  I think that this is what testing is all about...
confidence.  Unit testing gives you confidence in your objects. Integration
testing gives you confidence in the interaction between your objects.

My $.02

Michael

Subject: [junit] Unit Testing vs Integration Testing


I have experience with integration testing but not much with unit testing.
I've been reading up on unit testing  (e.g. mock objects, test first
development).  However, I have not found an article that explains the
advantages of unit testing vs integration testing.  My perhaps naive hunch
is that the cost-per-bug-eliminated of unit testing is higher than that of
integration testing.  It appears this way because a single integration test
tests a lot more code than a single unit test and takes about the same
amount of time to construct.  Plus it seems to me that a whole suite of unit
tests with 100% code coverage cannot guarantee that even the simplest system
wide behavior is correct (e.g. the web page appears).  Am I wrong about
this?  Can someone refer me information about this topic.  A scientific
study paper with real numbers would be welcome.

Mike Bresnahan
